page.title: 01FORMBY POINT
page.content: THIS AREA IS MAINLY THE SHALLOW, TIDAL WATERS OF LIVERPOOL BAY. IT IS ON THE WESTERN MARGIN OF FORMBY A DORMITORY TOWN TO THE NORTH-WEST OF LIVERPOOL. AT LOW TIDE, WATER-FILLED SHALLOWS ARE EXPOSED. REMAINS OF AN OLD BURIED FOREST CAN BE SEEN. BEHIND THE BEACH THERE ARE SAND-DUNES AND INLAND IS AN AREA WHICH BELONGS TO AND IS MANAGED BY THE NATIONAL TRUST. THE NATIONAL TRUST LAND COMPRISES A DUNE AREA AND A WOODLAND AREA. THESE DUNES ARE COVERED WITH PINE PLANTAINS, PLANTED AT THE END OF THE NINETEENTH CENTURY TO PREVENT EROSION AND TO FORM A WIND- BREAK FOR THE COMMERCIAL ASPARAGUS FIELDS WHICH NOW LIE DORMANT. THE WOODLAND AREA IS MADE UP OF NATURALLY SEEDED OAK, ALDER, SILVER BIRCH AND HAWTHORN WITH AN UNDERGROWTH OF BRAMBLE, CREEPING WILLOW AND GRASS.
